hs.set_parameters(new_parameters) self.assertEqual(hs._parameters, new_parameters) @mock.patch(CLS_NAME + '._wait_state') @mock.patch(CLS_NAME + '._get_status') def test_set_hot_env_and_files(self, status_get, wait_st): status_get.return_value = 'NOT_FOUND' wait_st.return_value = {} CONF.set_override('stack_tags', ['test-murano', 'murano-tag'], 'heat', enforce_type=True) hs = heat_stack.HeatStack('test-stack', None) hs._description = None hs._template = {'resources': {'test': 1}} hs._files = {} hs._hot_environment = '' hs._parameters = {} hs._applied = False hs._tags = ','.join(CONF.heat.stack_tags) hs.push() expected_template = { 'heat_template_version': '2013-05-23', 'resources': {'test': 1} } self.heat_client_mock.stacks.create.assert_called_with( stack_name='test-stack', disable_rollback=True, parameters={}, template=expected_template, files={}, environment='', tags=','.join(CONF.heat.stack_tags) ) new_hot_env = 'test' new_files = {'files': {'test': 1}} hs.set_hot_environment(new_hot_env) self.assertEqual(hs._hot_environment, new_hot_env) hs.set_files(new_files) self.assertEqual(hs._files, new_files) @mock.patch(CLS_NAME + '._wait_state') @mock.patch(CLS_NAME + '._get_status') def test_none_template(self, status_get, wait_st): status_get.return_value = 'NOT_FOUND' wait_st.return_value = {} CONF.set_override('stack_tags', ['test-murano', 'murano-tag'], 'heat', enforce_type=True) hs = heat_stack.HeatStack('test-stack', None) hs._description = None hs._template = None hs._files = {} hs._hot_environment = '' hs._parameters = {} hs._applied = True hs._tags = ','.join(CONF.heat.stack_tags) self.assertEqual(hs.push(), None)

import murano.tests.unit.base as test_base from murano.tests.unit import utils as test_utils from murano import utils class TestUtils(test_base.MuranoTestCase): def _patch_mock_session(self, mock_session, patch_obj): """Helper function for setting the return value of db_session.""" mock_session.get_session.return_value = mock.MagicMock( query=mock.MagicMock(return_value=mock.MagicMock( get=mock.MagicMock(return_value=patch_obj)))) @mock.patch('murano.utils.db_session') def test_check_env(self, mock_session): """Test check env.""" mock_request = mock.MagicMock(context=test_utils.dummy_context()) mock_env = mock.MagicMock(environment_id='test_env_id', tenant_id=mock_request.context.tenant) self._patch_mock_session(mock_session, mock_env) env = utils.check_env(mock_request, mock_env.environment_id) self.assertEqual(mock_env, env) @mock.patch('murano.utils.db_session') def test_check_env_with_null_environment_id(self, mock_session): """Test check env with null environment id throws exception.""" mock_request = mock.MagicMock(context=test_utils.dummy_context()) self._patch_mock_session(mock_session, None) test_env_id = 'test_env_id' expected_error_message = 'Environment with id {env_id} not found'\ .format(env_id=test_env_id) with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPNotFound, expected_error_message): utils.check_env(mock_request, test_env_id) @mock.patch('murano.utils.db_session') def test_check_env_with_mismatching_tenant_id(self, mock_session): """Test check env without matching tenant ids throws exception.""" mock_request = mock.MagicMock(context=test_utils.dummy_context()) mock_env = mock.MagicMock(environment_id='test_env_id', tenant_id='another_test_tenant_id') self._patch_mock_session(mock_session, mock_env) expected_error_message = 'User is not authorized to access these '\ 'tenant resources' with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPForbidden, expected_error_message): utils.check_env(mock_request, mock_env.environment_id) def test_check_session_with_null_session(self): """Test check session with null session throws exception.""" expected_error_message = 'Session <SessionId {id}> is not found'\ .format(id=None) with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPNotFound, expected_error_message): utils.check_session(None, None, None, None) @mock.patch('murano.utils.check_env') def test_check_session_with_mismatching_environment_id(self, _): """Test check session without matching env ids throws exception.""" mock_session = mock.MagicMock(session_id='session_id', environment_id='environment_id') environment_id = 'another_environment_id' expected_error_message = 'Session <SessionId {session_id}> is not tied' ' with Environment <EnvId {environment_id}>'\ .format(session_id=mock_session.session_id, environment_id=environment_id) with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPBadRequest, expected_error_message): utils.check_session(None, environment_id, mock_session, mock_session.session_id) def test_verify_session_with_invalid_request_header(self): """Test session with invalid request header throws exception.""" dummy_context = test_utils.dummy_context() if dummy_context.session: dummy_context.session = None mock_request = mock.MagicMock(context=dummy_context) expected_error_message = 'X-Configuration-Session header which '\ 'indicates to the session is missed' with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPBadRequest, expected_error_message): self._test_verify_session(mock_request) @mock.patch('murano.utils.db_session') def test_verify_session_with_null_session(self, mock_session): """Test null session throws expected exception.""" mock_request = mock.MagicMock(context=test_utils.dummy_context()) mock_request.context.session = mock.MagicMock( return_value='test_sess_id') self._patch_mock_session(mock_session, None) expected_error_message = 'Session <SessionId {0}> is not found'\ .format(mock_request.context.session) with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPNotFound, expected_error_message): self._test_verify_session(mock_request) @mock.patch('murano.utils.db_session') def test_verify_env_template_with_invalid_tenant(self, mock_session): """Test session validation failure throws expected exception.""" mock_request = mock.MagicMock(context=test_utils.dummy_context()) mock_request.context.tenant = mock.MagicMock( return_value='test_tenant_id') self._patch_mock_session( mock_session, mock.MagicMock(tenant_id='another_test_tenant_id')) expected_error_message = 'User is not authorized to access this'\ ' tenant resources' with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPForbidden, expected_error_message): self._test_verify_env_template(mock_request, None) @mock.patch('murano.utils.db_session') def test_verify_env_template_with_null_template(self, mock_session): """Test null env template throws expected exception.""" self._patch_mock_session(mock_session, None) expected_error_message = 'Environment Template with id {id} not found'\ .format(id='test_env_template_id') with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPNotFound, expected_error_message): self._test_verify_env_template(None, 'test_env_template_id') @utils.verify_env_template def _test_verify_env_template(self, request, env_template_id): """Helper function for testing above decorator.""" pass @mock.patch('murano.utils.sessions.SessionServices.validate') @mock.patch('murano.utils.db_session') def test_verify_session_with_invalid_session(self, mock_session, mock_validate): """Test session validation failure throws expected exception.""" mock_validate.return_value = False mock_request = mock.MagicMock(context=test_utils.dummy_context()) mock_request.context.session = mock.MagicMock( return_value='test_sess_id') self._patch_mock_session(mock_session, mock.MagicMock()) expected_error_message = 'Session <SessionId {0}> is invalid: '\ 'environment has been updated or '\ 'updating right now with other session'\ .format(mock_request.context.session) with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPForbidden, expected_error_message): self._test_verify_session(mock_request) @mock.patch('murano.utils.sessions.SessionServices.validate') @mock.patch('murano.utils.db_session') def test_verify_session_in_deploying_state(self, mock_session, mock_validate): """Test deploying session throws expected exception.""" mock_validate.return_value = True mock_request = mock.MagicMock(context=test_utils.dummy_context()) mock_request.context.session = mock.MagicMock( return_value='test_sess_id') self._patch_mock_session( mock_session, mock.MagicMock(state=states.SessionState.DEPLOYING)) expected_error_message = 'Session <SessionId {0}> is already in '\ 'deployment state'\ .format(mock_request.context.session) with self.assertRaisesRegexp(exc.HTTPForbidden, expected_error_message): self._test_verify_session(mock_request) @utils.verify_session def _test_verify_session(self, request): """Helper function for testing above decorator.""" pass @mock.patch('murano.utils.os') def test_ensure_tree(self, mock_os): """Test ensure tree throws the expected exceptions. Because OSError is a built-in exception, setattr() can't be called to change its errno. """ mock_os.path.isdir.return_value = False os_error = None path = os.path.realpath(__file__) try: os.makedirs(path) except OSError as e: os_error = e self.assertEqual(errno.EEXIST, os_error.errno) self.assertFalse(os.path.isdir(path)) mock_os.makedirs.side_effect = os_error self.assertRaises(OSError, utils.ensure_tree, path) mock_os.path.isdir.return_value = True path = os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)) try: os.makedirs(path) except OSError as e: os_error = e self.assertEqual(errno.EEXIST, os_error.errno) self.assertTrue(os.path.isdir(path)) mock_os.makedirs.side_effect = os_error result = utils.ensure_tree(path) self.assertFalse(result)

commit_message:
extending trove to better utilize storage capabilities

This is a specification to address two related areas of improvement in
Trove. Earlier these were felt to be independent, or seperable, but in
investigating them it seemed impossible to really take the two apart.

This specification has a lot of high level information (at this stage)
and is in need of a lot of low level details. I was originally
planning to push this spec up later with more of a completed
implementation, but based on a conversation with some folks yesterday,
I offered to push this up sooner so others have some idea of what I'm
currently planning/working on.

blueprint configurable-data-storage
blueprint snapshot-as-backup-strategy

Change-Id: Ie40b15e1a10e69c94a7ccc9b6b0842967497d980
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/52/302952/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/juno-template.rst =================================================== Configurable Data Storage for Trove Persistent Data =================================================== .. If section numbers are desired, unindent this .. sectnum:: .. If a TOC is desired, unindent this .. contents:: Currently Trove stores persistent data either on ephemeral volume, or an attached Cinder volume. This is restrictive and it would be beneficial for Trove to be able to interface with some other kinds of abstractions. One example is to be able to store data on Manila based folders. This specifically describes the benefits and implementation of an abstraction that would support Manila [1]_. Launchpad Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/configurable-data-storage Problem Description =================== The current implementation of Trove does not make it easy to add an alternative persistent storage method. The choices, ephemeral volume or Cinder volume are the only ones possible and the granularity at which this choice can be made is also very coarse-grained. The code does not modularize the underlying persistent storage method and therefore the code that manipulates the storage is fairly scattered around the code base. This is a problem given that some databases could really benefit from other kinds of persistent storage backends. Oracle, for example, is regularly run on NFS shared storage. MySQL is often run with a ZFS based shared backend storage system. Other database technologies can be configured to use raw devices or block devices (i.e. without a filesystem). These are all things that are not currently possible in Trove and the aim here is to make them possible. Proposed Change =============== The change(s) being proposed as part of this blueprint will alter the way in which Trove databases store their persistent data. Currently, the choice(s) are whether a given datastore will store its data on a Cinder volume, or whether that datastore will store data on an ephemeral volume. The change(s) being proposed will alter the current behavior in the following ways: 1. A trove database instance may store data on more than just a Cinder volume, or an ephemeral volume. A mechanism of persistent storage strategies will be created that allows for extensibility. In the initial implementation, we will provide support for at least the existing options (Cinder and ephemeral), and one new option. The proposal is written with the view that this new option is Manila [1]_. We will call these persistent-storage-strategies. 2. The operator will be able to specify which persistent-storage-strategies are allowed for each datastore. The operator will be further able to restrict which persistent-storage-strategies are allowed for each Trove guest image registered in Glance. This is similar to the way in which we can specify flavor, and or volume-type restrictions (proposed) on specific datastore versions. 3. The user (requestor of a database) will be able to choose a persistent storage location, at instance creation time, from amongst the persistent-storage-strategies permitted by the operator for the datastore and image. 4. All of the things that one can currently do with the existing two options should be made possible with the new persistent-storage-strategies. For example, the ability to resize a Cinder volume should be possible with the new implementation. 5. If a persistent-storage-strategy supports a notion of a snapshot that can be used to generate a clone, then that capability should be exposed and available to Trove. 6. Another important aspect of these changes is that the persistent-storage-strategies should be abstracted in such a way as to make it possible to use them as the basis for other things, like backup, or generation of a base-state for replication, and so on. - in situations where users have a small (relative) data set and would like to clone the data set and quickly lanch a database instance with that data, the ability of a storage mechanism which can quickly clone a data set is invaluable. This is also very important for accelerating replication (creation of a new replica) which can avoid the current backup-to-swift. - in situations where users have a production database which is in operation, the ability to a non-disruptive snapshot is invaluable. At some point if it is found that the database is corrupt, or the user determines for whatever reason that the database state should be rolled back to a previous state, it would be invaluable to be able to leverage this capability for disaster-recovery situations. 7. Current limitations of Trove include the fact that only a single persistent storage volume may be attached to an instance at a time. It would be advisable to lift this restriction for a number of reasons. The first is that many datbases would rather have dedicated volumes (logical) for data, log, and logging. This should also be addressed as part of the present project. In cases where the underlying storage supports a capability (such as volume groups) where multiple volumes are attached to a single instance, the ability to leverage the snapshot of a consistency group could be used to produce a backup of an instance. 8. Clusters have additional demands on storage and in situations where the underlying storage supports a capability (such as volume groups) where the volumes are attached to multiple instances, the ability to take a snapshot of the consistency group could be used to produce a backup of a cluster. One thing that makes the proposed strategy complex is that it straddles the controller and the guest. While the controller will create the persistent storage, and retain the id of the storage it created, the actual process of mounting, formatting and accessing the storage occurs on the guest. This is unlike other strategies that we have today. This means that there will be code in the strategy that can execute on one locus but not the other, and this will be confusing, at best. The change will introduce the following files and directories. All of the objects being created will be in trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage. A high level abstraction (abstraction base class) of storage will be provided in base.py. Implementations in cinder.py and ephemeral.py will provide support for the two currently known representations of persistent data, the names are self explanatory. Experimental strategies for the manila implementation will also be provided. .. code-block:: bash trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage/__init__.py trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage/base.py trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage/cinder.py trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage/ephemeral.py trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage/experimental trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage/experimental/manila trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage/experimental/manila/__init__.py trove/common/strategies/persistent-storage/experimental/manila/manila.py There will be changes to the prepare() call to the guest as the new prepare call will provide information about the persistent storage volume as well. To accomplish this, the guest configuration fill will have a new option indicating the persistent storage strategy so the guest agent code can load the appropriate implementation. The code in the guest agent for each datastore now handles some basic persistent storage actions during the prepare processing. These include formatting the storage, mounting and unmounting the device and so on. For example, consider this code in trove/guestagent/datastore/mysql_common/manager.py .. code-block:: python def do_prepare(self, context, packages, databases, memory_mb, users, device_path, mount_point, backup_info, config_contents, root_password, overrides, cluster_config, snapshot): """This is called from prepare in the base class.""" app = self.mysql_app(self.mysql_app_status.get()) app.install_if_needed(packages) if device_path: # stop and do not update database app.stop_db( do_not_start_on_reboot=self.volume_do_not_start_on_reboot) device = volume.VolumeDevice(device_path) # unmount if device is already mounted device.unmount_device(device_path) device.format() if os.path.exists(mount_point): # rsync existing data to a "data" sub-directory # on the new volume device.migrate_data(mount_point, target_subdir="data") # mount the volume device.mount(mount_point) operating_system.chown(mount_point, service.MYSQL_OWNER, service.MYSQL_OWNER, recursive=False, as_root=True) Observe the various calls that manipulate the persistent storage. First, the code determines whether or not the persistent storage is ephemeral volume or not based on the value of device_path. If device_path is None, the code understands that the persistent volume is ephemeral. In the event that the device_path is not None, the code stops the database (which is installed and running on the data directory which is part of the root file system) and prepares the mounted persistent storage before migrating the data directory to the new location and finally mounting the storage. All of these operations will be required for some of the implementations of the persistent storage strategey and common abstractions will be provided to facilitate common code in do_prepare(). Another kind of operation that is currently performed is to get file system volume stats. This code from datastore/manager.py .. code-block:: python def get_filesystem_stats(self, context, fs_path): """Gets the filesystem stats for the path given.""" mount_point = CONF.get(self.manager).mount_point LOG.debug("Getting file system stats for '%s'" % mount_point) return dbaas.get_filesystem_volume_stats(mount_point) We would need to provide suitable abstractions in each persistent storage strategy to get this information. While those are examples of code that only run on the guest, consider resize_fs which has a taskmanager component and a guest component. The persistent storage strategy will provide code that can handle both sides of this. Configuration ------------- This change will impact controller side configurations. The operator will be allowed to specify all the supported persistent storage strategies that will be allowed to be used on the OpenStack deployment. More details must be added here, and this specification is evolving. Database -------- The datastore_version_metadata table will be used to store the list of persistent storage strategies that will be allowed to be used for each datastore. This will provide an association (like flavors and volume types). Public API ---------- The create API call will include a persistent storage strategy option. This will validated against the list of allowed persistent storage strategies on the deployment and on the datastore. More details must be added here, and this specification is evolving and will be updated with more details. Public API Security ------------------- No change. Python API ---------- As in Public API above. CLI (python-troveclient) ------------------------ As in Public API above. Internal API ------------ Yes, in several ways including (most notably) the fact that the prepare call will now have additional information about the persistent storage strategy to be used. Guest Agent ----------- Yes, as described in Internal API above. The change is NOT backward compatible beyond that the guest with the new capabilities will work fine with a controller plane that has no knowledge of these new capabilities. Many of the changes will be in the Guest Agent(s) as described above. As this spec evolves, we will update this section with more details. Alternatives ------------ One consideration was to implement persistent storage NOT as a strategy. It turned out that not only would this have been more restrictive and less 'pluggable', but attempting to make it more flexible and pluggable arrived at an implementation that looked like a strategy. Therefore, I think implementing this as a strategy makes the most sense. Several alternatives were considered with respect to the layout of the persistent storage strategy. The key contenders were to make it like clustering (with a guestagent.py and a taskmanager.py) and like the swift (storage) strategy. The latter seems to be better and that's the approach being proposed here. Dashboard Impact (UX) ===================== During instance creation, the option to choose a specific persistent storage strategy will be provided. If one isn't provided, the cinder based strategy will be used. This and other changes are surely going to be felt in the dashboard. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Dashboard assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: eg. Liberty-1 Work Items ---------- Will be filled in later Upgrade Implications ==================== Changes to the guest must be made before changes to the controller. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Existing tests will be updated to reflect the new strategies. New tests will be provided for the new strategies. Documentation Impact ==================== Yes, there will be documentation impact. References ========== .. [1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Manila Appendix ======== None

commit_message:
Cleanup _open_writer and related methods

To avoid some of try/catch blocks to close writer (or fd),
cleanup StorletInvocationProtocol._open_writer methods to
close everything as expected. And then add some tests to check
the close methods (writer.close or os.close(fd)) called.

*BONUS*
- Now, logger arg is required for StorletInvocationProtocol becouse some
  method called self.logger w/o checking the existence.

Change-Id: Ic10e05141bc74ea01f49c72ab117d4580c3f46f0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/storlets refs/changes/26/378326/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: writer = os.fdopen(fd, 'w') try: writer.close() except: pass

commit_message:
Always enable devstack service

When the plugin is enabled, we should always enable the service, there's
no benefit in having an extra invocation - and it can only confuse users
when they forget setting it up.

For more info see:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/devstack/plugins.html

Change-Id: Ifcabc0955cb54f66388cac0c74b70c70ba65a1f9

commit_message:
Extract oslo_messaging specific audit tests

Extract the whole class of tests that deals with oslo.messaging
notifications. This matches what we did with logging notifications.

Convert the tests to using mock fixtures rather than mock decorator
directly.

Change-Id: I805be038c1e4e1d2fe16328c44cfa03d793b0136
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/96/334296/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
TrivialFix: Using assertEqual instead of assertEquals

Following OpenStack Style Guidelines[1]: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#unit-tests-and-assertraises
[H234] assertEquals() logs a DeprecationWarning in Python 3.x,
use assertEqual() instead. The same goes for assertNotEquals().

Change-Id: Ifead6a86460107c0495ba00412853361ecef6e3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/80/377280/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use the mocking fixture in notifier tests

All the notifier tests end up mocking out the notifier object so lets
just do it once for all tests.

This also splits out the test that tries to use the logging notifier
because it's a different setup.

Change-Id: I159a2d34fe833b0bbac70c41d521bbe1dccbc09c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/95/334295/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collectionsimport fixturesNotification = collections.namedtuple('Notification', ['context', 'event_type', 'payload']) class TestNotifier(object): def __init__(self, raise_exc=False): self.calls = [] self.raise_exc = raise_exc def notify(self, context, event_type, payload): self.calls.append(Notification(context, event_type, payload)) if self.raise_exc: raise Exception('error') def reset(self): self.calls = [] @property def last(self): return self.calls[-1] @property def call_count(self): return len(self.calls) @property def called(self): return self.call_count > 0 def setUp(self): self.notifier = TestNotifier() p = 'keystonemiddleware.audit._notifier.create_notifier' f = fixtures.MockPatch(p, return_value=self.notifier) self.notifier_fixture = self.useFixture(f) super(AuditMiddlewareTest, self).setUp() self.middleware(req) # Check first notification with only 'request' call_args = self.notifier.calls[0] self.assertEqual('audit.http.request', call_args.event_type) self.assertEqual('/foo/bar', call_args.payload['requestPath']) self.assertEqual('pending', call_args.payload['outcome']) self.assertNotIn('reason', call_args.payload) self.assertNotIn('reporterchain', call_args.payload) # Check second notification with request + response call_args = self.notifier.calls[1] self.assertEqual('audit.http.response', call_args.event_type) self.assertEqual('/foo/bar', call_args.payload['requestPath']) self.assertEqual('success', call_args.payload['outcome']) self.assertIn('reason', call_args.payload) self.assertIn('reporterchain', call_args.payload) try: self.middleware(req) self.fail('Application exception has not been re-raised') except Exception: pass # Check first notification with only 'request' call_args = self.notifier.calls[0] self.assertEqual('audit.http.request', call_args.event_type) self.assertEqual('/foo/bar', call_args.payload['requestPath']) self.assertEqual('pending', call_args.payload['outcome']) self.assertNotIn('reporterchain', call_args.payload) # Check second notification with request + response call_args = self.notifier.calls[1] self.assertEqual('audit.http.response', call_args.event_type) self.assertEqual('/foo/bar', call_args.payload['requestPath']) self.assertEqual('unknown', call_args.payload['outcome']) self.assertIn('reporterchain', call_args.payload) self.middleware._process_request(req) self.assertTrue(self.notifier.called) self.middleware._process_response(req, webob.response.Response()) self.assertTrue(self.notifier.called) # Check GET/PUT request does not send notification self.middleware(req) self.middleware(req1) self.assertFalse(self.notifier.called) # Check non-GET/PUT request does send notification self.middleware(req2) self.assertEqual(2, self.notifier.call_count) call_args = self.notifier.calls[0] self.assertEqual('audit.http.request', call_args.event_type) self.assertEqual('/accept/foo', call_args.payload['requestPath']) call_args = self.notifier.calls[1] self.assertEqual('audit.http.response', call_args.event_type) self.assertEqual('/accept/foo', call_args.payload['requestPath']) middleware(req) self.assertEqual(2, self.notifier.call_count) # the Context is the first argument. Let's verify it. self.assertIsInstance(self.notifier.calls[0].context, dict) # ensure exact same context is used between request and response self.assertIs(self.notifier.calls[0].context, self.notifier.calls[1].context) middleware(req) self.assertIsNotNone(req.environ.get('cadf_event')) # ensure exact same event is used between request and response self.assertEqual(self.notifier.calls[0].payload['id'], self.notifier.calls[1].payload['id']) self.notifier.raise_exc = True middleware._process_request(req) self.assertTrue(self.notifier.called) self.notifier.raise_exc = False self.notifier.reset() middleware._process_response(req2, webob.response.Response()) self.assertTrue(self.notifier.called) # ensure event is not the same across requests self.assertNotEqual(req.environ['cadf_event'].id, self.notifier.calls[0].payload['id'])

Check GET/PUT request does not send notification self.middleware(req) self.middleware(req1) self.assertEqual([], notify.call_args_list) # Check non-GET/PUT request does send notification self.middleware(req2) self.assertThat(notify.call_args_list, matchers.HasLength(2)) call_args = notify.call_args_list[0][0] self.assertEqual('audit.http.request', call_args[1]) self.assertEqual('/accept/foo', call_args[2]['requestPath']) call_args = notify.call_args_list[1][0] self.assertEqual('audit.http.response', call_args[1]) self.assertEqual('/accept/foo', call_args[2]['requestPath']) def test_api_request_no_messaging(self): req = webob.Request.blank('/foo/bar', environ=self.get_environ_header('GET')) with mock.patch('keystonemiddleware.audit._notifier.oslo_messaging', None): with mock.patch('keystonemiddleware.audit._LOG.info') as log: self.middleware = audit.AuditMiddleware( base.FakeApp(), audit_map_file=self.audit_map) self.middleware(req) # Check first notification with only 'request' call_args = log.call_args_list[0][0] self.assertEqual('audit.http.request', call_args[1]['event_type']) # Check second notification with request + response call_args = log.call_args_list[1][0] self.assertEqual('audit.http.response', call_args[1]['event_type']) with mock.patch('oslo_messaging.Notifier.info') as notify: middleware(req) self.assertEqual(2, notify.call_count) first, second = [a[0] for a in notify.call_args_list] # the Context is the first argument. Let's verify it. self.assertIsInstance(first[0], dict) # ensure exact same context is used between request and response self.assertIs(first[0], second[0]) with mock.patch('oslo_messaging.Notifier.info') as notify: middleware(req) self.assertIsNotNone(req.environ.get('cadf_event')) # ensure exact same event is used between request and response self.assertEqual(notify.call_args_list[0][0][2]['id'], notify.call_args_list[1][0][2]['id']) with mock.patch('oslo_messaging.Notifier.info', side_effect=Exception('error')) as notify: middleware._process_request(req) self.assertTrue(notify.called) with mock.patch('oslo_messaging.Notifier.info') as notify: middleware._process_response(req2, webob.response.Response()) self.assertTrue(notify.called) # ensure event is not the same across requests self.assertNotEqual(req.environ['cadf_event'].id, notify.call_args_list[0][0][2]['id'])

commit_message:
Refactor CommandSuccess/Failure class with functool.partial

We don't need to define each class for success/failure, but can
use functool.partial to create an alias for them.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: If1844089a2d91c0103161ee2401873b40998b356
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/storlets refs/changes/83/378683/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from functools import partialCommandSuccess = partial(CommandResponse, True) CommandFailure = partial(CommandResponse, False)
deleted_lines: class CommandSuccess(CommandResponse): def __init__(self, message, iterable=True): super(CommandSuccess, self).__init__(True, message, iterable) class CommandFailure(CommandResponse): def __init__(self, message, iterable=True): super(CommandFailure, self).__init__(False, message, iterable)

commit_message:
Align the stars to bump RDO to Ocata

1) Bump RDO repository to the first consistent Ocata repository.
2) Adding lbaasv2 service plugin into Neutron, required to execute
   LBaaS tests.
3) Disabling Designate on RDO, it miss a new Monasca dependency.

Change-Id: Ib1c6144bd248c482f9dfe6d4ef6eab5c1a0a986d

commit_message:
Limit memory & CPU when running qemu-img info

It was found that a modified or corrupted image file can cause a DoS
on the host when getting image info with qemu-img.

This uses the newer 'prlimit' parameter for oslo.concurrency execute
to set an address space limit of 1GB and CPU time limit of 2 seconds
when running the qemu-img info command.

Change-Id: If5b7129b266ef065642bc7898ce9dcf93722a053
Closes-bug: #1449062
(cherry picked from commit 8547444775e406a50d9d26a0003e9ba6554b0d70)

Add E123,E125 check and Solve several problems

When We do not ignore E123 and E125,there are several problems.
They are more accordant with OpenStack Style Guidelines

commit_message:
Add Apache 2.0 license to source file

As per OpenStack licensing guide lines [1]:
[H102 H103] Newly contributed Source Code should be licensed under
the Apache 2.0 license.
[H104] Files with no code shouldn't contain any license header nor
comments, and must be left completely empty.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#openstack-licensing

Change-Id: Ife20ac7c37ca91430f71b4aface62fc43926c168
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/51/379251/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Clean up libvirt guest code
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-05 17:15:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ccf9db18e090e7f164d0f222da1b980983ecd79e', 'message': "Clean up libvirt guest code

Libvirt's function blockJobInfo returns structure with info about operation on
block device. In this structure there current and final value to indicate
current and final cursor position for operation, value of bandwidth for
operation and type of operation. All of those values are integer values and
can't be unset. Because of that there is no need to get those values with
specified defaults in BlockDevice.get_job_info() method.

Change-Id: I597f15cf330e192b7ad88549c8dfc2f52b13df57
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-09-06 13:36:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/62c42e9815b83285d942e3cb810120ec77b5eca1', 'message': "libvirt: Clean up block device job status reporting code

Libvirt's function blockJobInfo returns structure with info about
operation on block device. In this structure, there are four
fields: 'cur' and 'end' to indicate current and final cursor position
for a live block operation; 'bandwidth' to set bandwidth limit for
the active block operation; finally, 'type' to specify the type of
block operation (e.g. blockCommit(), blockRebase(), etc).
All of those values are integer values and can't be unset.
Because of that there is no need to get those values with specified
defaults in BlockDevice.get_job_info() method.

Change-Id: I597f15cf330e192b7ad88549c8dfc2f52b13df57
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-09-15 07:13:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d5d770a5a6f5718ac52fd616dc8e3f91e2634ec9', 'message': "Clean up libvirt guest code

Libvirt's function blockJobInfo returns structure with info about operation on
block device. In this structure there current and final value to indicate
current and final cursor position for operation, value of bandwidth for
operation and type of operation. All of those values are integer values and
can't be unset. Because of that there is no need to get those values with
specified defaults in BlockDevice.get_job_info() method.

Change-Id: I597f15cf330e192b7ad88549c8dfc2f52b13df57

commit_message:
Clean up libvirt guest code

Libvirt's function blockJobInfo returns structure with info about operation on
block device. In this structure there current and final value to indicate
current and final cursor position for operation, value of bandwidth for
operation and type of operation. All of those values are integer values and
can't be unset. Because of that there is no need to get those values with
specified defaults in BlockDevice.get_job_info() method.

Change-Id: I597f15cf330e192b7ad88549c8dfc2f52b13df57

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-28 14:25:52.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_context/tests/test_context.py', 'oslo_context/context.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.context/commit/61dd21320a11ea991b0c1395bc5294bc1341f117', 'message': "Add is_admin_project check

Keystone now has two configuration values:
   admin_project_name
   admin_project_domain_name

If both values are set, and tokens requested for projects
(only, not domains) that match both will have an additional
value in them;

   `is_admin_project=true`

THis value is indicates that the token can be used for operations that
are considered 'administrative' and which, in the past, only required.

this field.


Change-Id: I81a9a9f46a65f667002a61ad39cc6240c30114dc

commit_message:
Add is_admin_project check

Keystone now has two configuration values:
   admin_project_name
   admin_project_domain_name

If both values are set, and tokens requested for projects
(only, not domains) that match both will have an additional
value in them;

   `is_admin_project=true`

THis value is indicates that the token can be used for operations that
are considered 'administrative' and which, in the past, only required.
The 'admin' role.  This added check allows the services to
independantly close https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/968696 but
int order to do so, they need to be able to enforce policy against
this field.


Change-Id: I81a9a9f46a65f667002a61ad39cc6240c30114dc

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-05 16:32:49.000000000', 'files': ['test-vars.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests/commit/d0ff9cc1ba6d01864226ea53eb91effff3f4db6f', 'message': 'Remove workaround for bad pycparser wheel

commit_message:
Remove workaround for bad pycparser wheel

This reverts https://review.openstack.org/381007 now that the
root cause of the issue [1] has been resolved, and that the
upper-constraints for OpenStack have been updated [2] to work
around the issue.

It also adds a clearer explanation for the reason why
libvirt-python is not installed via a wheel in tests.

[1] https://github.com/eliben/pycparser/issues/147
[2] https://review.openstack.org/381011

Change-Id: I2a4e75d952d4218fa7a0847e6fbf8f6afc15a65b
(cherry picked from commit 783709a84e7abf69cc8c7174dc3467d776c00063)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests refs/changes/53/382553/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This ensures that libvirt-python is built from source. A pre-built # wheel can be missing libvirt capabilities from the installed version # of libvirt-bin, leading to nova-compute failing to start. pip_install_options: "--no-binary libvirt-python"
deleted_lines: # TODO(odyssey4me): Remove pycparser once https://github.com/eliben/pycparser/issues/147 is resolved # Note: libvirt-python is here to ensure that it always installs with the right binaries pip_install_options: "--no-binary pycparser --no-binary libvirt-python"

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-04 10:12:08.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/hot/functions.py', 'heat/tests/test_hot.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/89526b5ea7a88172b5298a5be79103ff5bb51a2b', 'message': 'Use empty list for None values in repeat function

Atrributes would return `None` before the resource is
created, hence resource validation would fail when
using repeat function. Use empty list instead to avoid
it.

Change-Id: I93f65d6604944ccae40f65ef52754dcec69e9886
Closes-Bug: #1629899
'}]
commit_message:
Use empty list for None values in repeat function

Atrributes would return `None` before the resource is
created, hence resource validation would fail when
using repeat function. Use empty list instead to avoid
it.

Change-Id: I93f65d6604944ccae40f65ef52754dcec69e9886
Closes-Bug: #1629899
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/96/381596/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_merge_containing_repeat_with_none(self): snippet = {'map_merge': {'repeat': {'template': {'ROLE': 'ROLE'}, 'for_each': {'ROLE': None}}}} tmpl = template.Template(hot_mitaka_tpl_empty) resolved = self.resolve(snippet, tmpl) self.assertEqual({}, resolved)

Having non-shebang first line (empty one) leads to error on Xenial,

"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-10-05 12:47:24.000000000', 'files': ['nodepool/elements/nodepool-base/finalise.d/89-unbound'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/db77edfa0cc3c4a04afd8222d61cc67cba39f3c7', 'message': "Fix rc.local for systemd in nodepool-base element

Change-Id: Icc2f01b89e6d582ad015009f6916379bee8af7b9
"}]
commit_message:
Fix rc.local for systemd in nodepool-base element

Having non-shebang first line (empty one) leads to error on Xenial,
because systemd can't execute scripts without shebang, and rc.local
is not run (`status=203/EXEC`).

Change-Id: Icc2f01b89e6d582ad015009f6916379bee8af7b9

commit_message:
Add options attribute to NFVSwitch

Adding options to NFVSwitch type bridge will give flexibility and
avoid specific attributes like 'cpus' in the yaml file (which will now
be moved into the options)

Change-Id: I4d715b641c54de969b9195b1a4b16195b2d7e595

deleted_lines: dhclient_args=None, dns_servers=None, cpus=""): self.cpus = cpus cpus = '' cpus_json = json.get('cpus') if cpus_json: if isinstance(cpus_json, basestring): cpus = cpus_json else: msg = '"cpus" must be a string of numbers separated by commas.' raise InvalidConfigException(msg) else: msg = 'Config "cpus" is mandatory.' dns_servers=dns_servers, cpus=cpus)

commit_message:
[Gates] Unblock rally verify gates

Three rally verify jenkins jobs

  gate-rally-dsvm-verify-full-discover-resources
  gate-rally-dsvm-verify-light-create-resources
  gate-rally-dsvm-verify-full-create-resources

fail very often because of the issue with the internet connection
on jenkins slaves. This patch is a temporary work around to unblock
rally verify gates and continue the development process further.

Change-Id: I1a301cd6ac0df8e33c8b06301f00dbbb2abc43bd

subject: Remove warning when no base venvs are found
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-05 16:40:45.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/repo_venv_pre_build.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build/commit/166c1d9d503723df02ad0cc28ec8afdaa25b4834', 'message': 'Remove warning when no base venvs are found

During the "Destroy base venvs to rebuild them" step ansible tries to
access base_venvs.stdout_lines. If no base_venvs have been registered
previously, this causes a deprecation warning because stdout_lines is
undefined.
This is a small fix to remove this warning by giving an empty list as
default value when stdout_lines is not defined.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I358709f3d4dc10a60f59976f1c4fbf87705def57
(cherry picked from commit 851e3ffd09544b655e20997a4e586452b7f6a583)
'}]
commit_message:
Remove warning when no base venvs are found

During the "Destroy base venvs to rebuild them" step ansible tries to
access base_venvs.stdout_lines. If no base_venvs have been registered
previously, this causes a deprecation warning because stdout_lines is
undefined.
This is a small fix to remove this warning by giving an empty list as
default value when stdout_lines is not defined.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I358709f3d4dc10a60f59976f1c4fbf87705def57
(cherry picked from commit 851e3ffd09544b655e20997a4e586452b7f6a583)

commit_message:
Add "daily" option to bugdaystats.py

Recently, we are triaging bugs of Tempest on the launchpad and that
work was fine to clean up old bugs and fixed bugs with different
patches.
Current bugdaystats shows it in last several days statically, and it
would be nice to add more long terms like in 30 days or a release to see
bug triage trends.

This patch adds a "daily" option to bugdaystats.py for making daily data
json files. The file can be used to show long term data in other graphs.

Change-Id: Ieac396389ce13468b717d03264164c77f7c36104
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bugdaystats refs/changes/49/358149/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def update_stats(outputpath, project_name, rotation, daily=False): if daily: filename = "%s-bug-stats-daily.json" % project_name else: filename = "%s-bug-stats.json" % project_name project_stats_filename = os.path.join(outputpath, filename) if daily: if (now - record['date']) < (24 * 60 * 60): # Skip to update stats if the recode contains the same # day data. return # The rotation of daily data is a half year because of a # single development cycle. update_stats(outputpath, p['project'], 183, daily=True)
deleted_lines: def update_stats(outputpath, project_name, rotation): project_stats_filename = os.path.join(outputpath, "%s-bug-stats.json" % (project_name))

commit_message:
Do not use yaql input data conversion

When root is set to context manually it will not
be converted into immutable object and task serialization
will do faster because it does not spent time to this conversion

Related-Bug: 1569859
Change-Id: I46e4c43a757b78d96eec3edea0f66361afae3d73

commit_message:
Standardize the testing for Cinder

This PR standardizes the testing around the central tests repository:

* Removes the install-cinder and prepare-vg playbooks
* Moves the inventory settings into host_vars
* Adjusts the "bridges" settings
* Standardize IP addresses on the 10.1.1.0/24 range

Change-Id: I91c8079b033bb83e0175a3ab4b1c020a8df4a0db
Depends-On: Ibe2bcd91af9eac099e86e92f9294ed04fffe7b95

commit_message:
Clean up requests-mock usage

In line with other clients testing we've found that having the
requests-mock fixture at self.requests can be misleading for new people
as it looks like you're calling requests itself.

Also make use of some of the new features of requests-mock like query
parsing, json handling, method names.

Change-Id: Id61b88c53478d49f91c3f880ed5b90d638051ba0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/99/381499/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Replace requests mocking with requests-mock

The novaclient tests are broken with the master (unreleased) branch of
requests. This is because most of the mocking that novaclient does with
requests in insufficient.

Requests-mock is for exactly this purpose and is already widely used in
novaclient so replace using mock with requests-mock where appropriate.

Closes-Bug: #1630157
Change-Id: Ie91daeb5f0c241eb83b77c04ac1b12e431d6671c

subject: Remove warning when no base venvs are found
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-05 14:02:30.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/repo_venv_pre_build.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build/commit/851e3ffd09544b655e20997a4e586452b7f6a583', 'message': 'Remove warning when no base venvs are found

During the "Destroy base venvs to rebuild them" step ansible tries to
access base_venvs.stdout_lines. If no base_venvs have been registered
previously, this causes a deprecation warning because stdout_lines is
undefined.
This is a small fix to remove this warning by giving an empty list as
default value when stdout_lines is not defined.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I358709f3d4dc10a60f59976f1c4fbf87705def57
'}]
commit_message:
Remove warning when no base venvs are found

During the "Destroy base venvs to rebuild them" step ansible tries to
access base_venvs.stdout_lines. If no base_venvs have been registered
previously, this causes a deprecation warning because stdout_lines is
undefined.
This is a small fix to remove this warning by giving an empty list as
default value when stdout_lines is not defined.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I358709f3d4dc10a60f59976f1c4fbf87705def57
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build refs/changes/33/382433/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Remove usage of --control-scale from the replace controller docs

This CLI arg was deprecated in Newton in favour of using the param in a
environment file.

commit_message:
Allow db user name differing from db name

For some services, the name of the database user may differ from the
name of the database that user needs access to. Add a 'db_user' variable
for use in this case, defaulting to 'db_name' to maintain current
functionality.

Change-Id: Iff2d736415cfbe3e1ec60aa370cc30bd8610541d

commit_message:
Checksum all traffic traveling though the bridges

Some tests requiring accessing OpenStack APIs from within a VM may fail
due to networking problems caused by invalid checksums. This change
simply changes the checksum rules from only port 22 to all ports.

Related-bug: #1619730
Co-Authored-By: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

Change-Id: If2e6180ec999f09e89944faa0a2b195dd81fba0e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests refs/changes/05/381305/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Add iptables rule to ensure traffic checksum is correct command: /sbin/iptables -A POSTROUTING -t mangle -p tcp -j CHECKSUM --checksum-fill
deleted_lines: - name: Add iptables rule to ensure ssh checksum is correct command: /sbin/iptables -A POSTROUTING -t mangle -p tcp --dport 22 -j CHECKSUM --checksum-fill

commit_message:
[UG] New Troubleshooting sections

This patch adds the following articles to the
Troubleshooting section of Fuel UG:

- Restarting an OpenStack service
- Enabling debug mode
- Logging OS services
- Check OS services status

commit_message:
Remove workaround for bad pycparser wheel

This reverts https://review.openstack.org/381007 now that the
root cause of the issue [1] has been resolved, and that the
upper-constraints for OpenStack have been updated [2] to work
around the issue.

It also adds a clearer explanation for the reason why
libvirt-python is not installed via a wheel in tests.

[1] https://github.com/eliben/pycparser/issues/147
[2] https://review.openstack.org/381011

Change-Id: I2a4e75d952d4218fa7a0847e6fbf8f6afc15a65b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests refs/changes/92/381592/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This ensures that libvirt-python is built from source. A pre-built # wheel can be missing libvirt capabilities from the installed version # of libvirt-bin, leading to nova-compute failing to start. pip_install_options: "--no-binary libvirt-python"
deleted_lines: # TODO(odyssey4me): Remove pycparser once https://github.com/eliben/pycparser/issues/147 is resolved # Note: libvirt-python is here to ensure that it always installs with the right binaries pip_install_options: "--no-binary pycparser --no-binary libvirt-python"

commit_message:
TrivialFix: Remove default=None when set value in Config

By default oslo.cfg sets the default values as None [1], There is
no need to explicitly do this.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.config/blob/master/oslo_config/cfg.py#L829

Change-Id: I5cf1380aa2b0cb9e953da30d7fa66a5b5d795161

commit_message:
Add linux-image-extra to host packages

When the host is installed, the loading of the kernel module
'vhost_net' may fail due to the module not being installed.

This results in the following error when trying to load the
vhost_net module:

modprobe: FATAL: Module vhost_net not found.

This patch ensures that the appropriate linux-image-extra package
for the running kernel is installed.

Combined backport of:
- https://review.openstack.org/335650
- https://review.openstack.org/382410

Change-Id: If2f008357117495c9e4b80dbfef68503fa93a809
Closes-Bug: 1595323
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts refs/changes/42/382442/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-05 14:03:08.000000000', 'files': ['vars/ubuntu-14.04.yml', 'vars/ubuntu-16.04.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts/commit/bc52b0b66b6a63c32f5071cb9558cb1cab643da5', 'message': "Ensure that linux-image-extra matches running kernel

When the host is installed, the loading of the kernel module
'vhost_net' may fail due to the module not being installed.

Currently the role installs the 'linux-image-extra-virtual'
package which will install the latest kernel and latest
extras package, but this may not match the running kernel on
the host.

This results in the following error when trying to load the
vhost_net module:

modprobe: FATAL: Module vhost_net not found.

This patch ensures that the linux-image-extra package

Change-Id: I08271fcdfae3977f202ad7d6b03f61ab00e64370
(cherry picked from commit 23ad4822cc8822378ab1d64037b5eb722a1dedd3)
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure that linux-image-extra matches running kernel

When the host is installed, the loading of the kernel module
'vhost_net' may fail due to the module not being installed.

Currently the role installs the 'linux-image-extra-virtual'
package which will install the latest kernel and latest
extras package, but this may not match the running kernel on
the host.

This results in the following error when trying to load the
vhost_net module:

modprobe: FATAL: Module vhost_net not found.

This patch ensures that the linux-image-extra package
installed matches that of the running kernel.

Change-Id: I08271fcdfae3977f202ad7d6b03f61ab00e64370
(cherry picked from commit 23ad4822cc8822378ab1d64037b5eb722a1dedd3)

commit_message:
Moving of Nova scenarios into separate classes

Since current scenario implementation transforms method to class
at runtime, it is reasonable to have class-based scenario
implementation which will be much simpler to use behind the scenes.

This class should be based on Scenario and do not break compatibility.
The only required method is run() which is actually a body of scenario.

Change-Id: If6d69aa6b16d1aa3745422e772bca98e6c4eaf9a

commit_message:
Heka template missing optional params

If enable_rabbitmq or enable_keystone are false, the configs will not be
copied to target nodes for these. This resulted in Heka failing to
start.

Change-Id: I93d15534802b671f1f42e8b2dfb523a17526ffb7

python -m pytest

  * Using python -m pytest instead of py.test-VERSION.
  * Using pkgos-dh_auto_install from openstack-pkg-tools >= 52~.
  * Other fixes already in Debian.

commit_message:
Add patch to fix py3.5 issue

  * Add Do_not_require_entry-point_dependencies_in_tests.patch

Change-Id: I9fe3ff9ceb4613e389438337b0b8517b76668bf3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/deb-python-glance-store refs/changes/83/382483/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Description: Do not require entry-point dependencies in tests Author: Ian Cordasco <graffatcolmingov@gmail.com> Date: Wed, 5 Oct 2016 13:19:36 +0000 (-0500) X-Git-Url: https://review.openstack.org/gitweb?p=openstack%2Fglance_store.git;a=commitdiff_plain;h=6903ae45e756f0a2e65f811d6b8b7ad045a78800 In our tests, we load our entry-points using plain pkg_resources and in doing so were requiring our dependencies to be checked for each plugin. This was causing test errors on Python 3.5 running on some environments. . By using logic to load the entry-points as modern versions of setuptools expect us to and defaulting requirement verification to False, we should avoid these testing errors. Change-Id: Id58861f72d399758178e0f11f617d2f178eddc4a Closes-bug: #1630392 Origin: upstream, https://review.openstack.org/382406 Last-Update: 2016-10-05 diff --git a/glance_store/tests/unit/test_opts.py b/glance_store/tests/unit/test_opts.py index 2d85a05..ef73c4b 100644 --- a/glance_store/tests/unit/test_opts.py +++ b/glance_store/tests/unit/test_opts.py @@ -20,6 +20,18 @@ from glance_store import backend from glance_store.tests import base +def load_entry_point(entry_point, verify_requirements=False): + """Load an entry-point without requiring dependencies.""" + resolve = getattr(entry_point, 'resolve', None) + require = getattr(entry_point, 'require', None) + if resolve is not None and require is not None: + if verify_requirements: + entry_point.require() + return entry_point.resolve() + else: + return entry_point.load(require=verify_requirements) + + class OptsTestCase(base.StoreBaseTest): def _check_opt_groups(self, opt_list, expected_opt_groups): @@ -43,7 +55,7 @@ class OptsTestCase(base.StoreBaseTest): opt_list = None for ep in pkg_resources.iter_entry_points('oslo.config.opts'): if ep.name == namespace: - list_fn = ep.load() + list_fn = load_entry_point(ep) opt_list = list_fn() break

commit_message:
Use service-specific servernames for haproxy

Right now we're hardcoding the server names for the services to be
the controllers. This is problematic if we start  using custom roles
for services, which listen on nodes that are not controllers.

We already have the server names for each service, so using this
mapping instead fixes the issue.

Change-Id: Ic4b65edb3dc1b75abbc3421a87cab97425b058c4
Closes-Bug: #1629098

commit_message:
DNM: This is a test

This commit attempts to exerice the new check experimental jobs I've

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-04 18:09:51.000000000', 'files': ['networking_powervm/plugins/ibm/agent/powervm/sriov_agent.py', 'networking_powervm/tests/unit/plugins/ibm/powervm/test_sriov_agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-powervm/commit/7820ccd92029b3000f34773c92fc9a67788825c5', 'message': "Time out port update waiting for vif plug

When the SR-IOV agent receives a port update notice from neutron, it
polls the server waiting for the corresponding vNIC to be created before
marking the port as active.  If the vNIC create errors or doesn't
happen, the agent would keep polling for that vNIC indefinitely.

With this change set, if the vNIC doesn't spring into existence within
20 minutes, the agent gives up and stops polling.  (If whatever caused
the vNIC not to be created hasn't already triggered rollback/cleanup of
the corresponding compute process, that process also times out after 20
minutes.)

Change-Id: I5fd640dfb799c51738aa3613852b4ac69decb31b

commit_message:
Time out port update waiting for vif plug

When the SR-IOV agent receives a port update notice from neutron, it
polls the server waiting for the corresponding vNIC to be created before
marking the port as active.  If the vNIC create errors or doesn't
happen, the agent would keep polling for that vNIC indefinitely.

With this change set, if the vNIC doesn't spring into existence within
20 minutes, the agent gives up and stops polling.  (If whatever caused
the vNIC not to be created hasn't already triggered rollback/cleanup of
the corresponding compute process, that process also times out after 20
minutes.)

Closes-Bug: #1629559
Change-Id: I5fd640dfb799c51738aa3613852b4ac69decb31b

commit_message:
Sort fixed_ips for ports

This is not really a substantial thing, because the order returned from
neutron is not defined and does not carry meaning. However, in
functional tests this has been on occasion unstable. So go ahead and
sort it because it's not hard. Also, this will put in a normalize hook
for ports which will be nice later.

Change-Id: Ifb79ded4bdf8ac095cca75894c3524268f9f97c5

commit_message:
Watcher utils cleanup

As some of our utils function are actually available in oslo.utils,
this patchset simply gets rid of our local copy and instead references
the oslo.utils one. This will help us deport the code maintenance of
these to a 3rd party library.

Change-Id: I3760ebab69d35c37bbe78500918d4e46b5bd9119

commit_message:
DevStack: disable Neutron compute services on initial node

In DevStack tests against Neutron master and stable/newton, we're seeing
lots of error logs like these:

[req-47312e0f-d29c-4809-adb2-85ddd8be6bbe - -] Exception during message handling
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/oslo_messaging/rpc/server.py", line 133, in _process_incoming
    res = self.dispatcher.dispatch(message)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/oslo_messaging/rpc/dispatcher.py", line 150, in dispatch
    return self._do_dispatch(endpoint, method, ctxt, args)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/oslo_messaging/rpc/dispatcher.py", line 121, in _do_dispatch
    result = func(ctxt, **new_args)
  File "/opt/stack/neutron/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/type_tunnel.py", line 398, in tunnel_sync
    raise exc.InvalidInput(error_message=msg)
InvalidInput: Invalid input for operation: Network type value 'vxlan' not supported.

But the processing needed in a deployment with Calico networking
shouldn't be going anywhere need the ML2 'tunnel' type driver...

Further investigation reveals that:
- the only caller of 'tunnel_sync' is the OVS agent
- neutron-openvswitch-agent is indeed running on the first node (with
  combined control/compute function) that is set up using
  networking-calico's DevStack settings
- other processes running, but that Calico doesn't actually want or
  need, are neutron-dhcp-agent, neutron-l3-agent and
  neutron-metadata-agent.

This commit disables those unwanted agents.

Change-Id: I510ab19bbea33739a6be1c0e727a0091edb4d9f0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-calico refs/changes/26/382426/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Disable Neutron services that we don't want. disable_service q-agt disable_service q-dhcp disable_service q-l3 disable_service q-meta

commit_message:
make the final release tool smarter

For newton we had several projects with pre-release versioning this
cycle that didn't use it for mitaka. We also had several projects with
their first release this time around. Both conditions made
propose-final-releases suggest the wrong diff-start values. This patch
applies the rules that I used by hand to ensure that the diff-start
values in I74b66ffd484f2f3a2b84c39e62bcb718cef7b906 were
correct. Running the tool against a local copy of the releases
repository produced a patchset that was logically equivalent to I74b66.

Change-Id: Ib5025991d28e661c334e3ea81d256362fba5c0ff
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/38/381338/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import atexitimport re import shutil import tempfilefrom releasetools import gitutils {diff_start_comment}diff-start: {diff_start}PRE_RELEASE = re.compile('(a|b|rc)') def get_prior_branch_point(workdir, repo, branch): """Return the tag of the base of the branch. The diff-start is the old version is the tag on the commit where we created the branch. To determine that, we need to clone the repo and look at the branch. See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-October/104901.html for a better description of what the desired tag info is. """ gitutils.clone_repo(workdir, repo) branch_base = gitutils.get_branch_base( workdir, repo, branch, ) if branch_base: return gitutils.get_latest_tag( workdir, repo, branch_base, ) # Work backwards from the most recent commit looking for the first # version that is not a pre-release, and assume that is the # previous release on a non-branching repository like for the # os-*-config tools. start = None while True: print(' looking for version before {}'.format(start)) version = gitutils.get_latest_tag(workdir, repo, start) if not version: return None if not PRE_RELEASE.search(version): return version start = '{}^'.format(version) return version '--no-cleanup', dest='cleanup', default=True, action='store_false', help='do not remove temporary files', ) parser.add_argument( 'prior_series', help='the name of the previous series', ) parser.add_argument( workdir = tempfile.mkdtemp(prefix='releases-') print('creating temporary files in %s' % workdir) def cleanup_workdir(): if args.cleanup: try: shutil.rmtree(workdir) except: pass else: print('not cleaning up %s' % workdir) atexit.register(cleanup_workdir) branch = 'stable/{}'.format(args.prior_series) diff_start = get_prior_branch_point( workdir, projects[0]['repo'], branch, ) diff_start_comment=('# ' if diff_start is None else ''),
deleted_lines: diff-start: {diff_start} def get_prior_branch_point(version): "Assuming we always branch on the rc1 tag..." parts = version.split('.') prior = int(parts[0]) - 1 return '{}.0.0.0rc1'.format(prior) diff_start = get_prior_branch_point(new_version)

subject: make the script for proposing final releases more flexible
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-30 16:02:01.000000000', 'files': ['releasetools/cmds/propose_final_releases.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/release-tools/commit/04dc16552b1d565800e788a5a026420c5e331e3a', 'message': "make the script for proposing final releases more flexible

commit_message:
make the script for proposing final releases more flexible

We have a few deliverables in newton for which there are no release
candidates, but there are other pre-releases (betas) from which we want
to cut the final release. Make the logic for finding them more flexible.

The result will still assume that we want to diff from the rc1, which
won't exist, but those values were always just suggestions so we will
need to fix them by hand anyway.

Change-Id: I7fddbc5fec28eb1fe27ccfffa6e9a5126bc51dfd
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/18/380418/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for pre_rel in ['a', 'b', 'rc']: if pre_rel in latest_release['version']: break else: # we did not find any pre_rel if args.verbose: print('# not a release candidate') # The new version is the same as the latest release version # without the pre-release component at the end. new_version = '.'.join( latest_release['version'].split('.')[:-1] )
deleted_lines: if 'rc' not in latest_release['version']: if args.verbose: print('# not a release candidate') new_version = latest_release['version'].split('.0rc')[0]

commit_message:
Replace create_test_network with network object

This patch will replace the creation of network with
Network object, previously object_db_api was directly
used given now object is introduced we can use it.

Change-Id: I11a73f033171151e97c868108eda39fe178722f4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/33/379633/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: # TODO(ihrachys): replace with network.create() once we get an object # implementation for networks self._network = obj_db_api.create_object(self.context, models_v2.Network, {'name': 'test-network1'})

commit_message:
Relocate Flavor and ServiceProfile DB models

This patch will separate flavor and service profile db models from
mixins for Oslo-Versioned Objects implementation work.

Change-Id: Ia35d24c075dc716e44fbf8a9b6a2ebb0297e7aa9
Partial-Bug: #1597913

commit_message:
Fix unit tests failure caused my fetch-mock update

In some unit tests mockOptions.name was used instead of
mockOptions.matcher, and it was always undefined - this stopped
working with fetch-mock 5.5.0. This commit replaces
mockOptions.name with mockOptions.matcher where it is needed.

Change-Id: I367e1d957ce206c20c6b9d15c9f5ff1a2b285e33

deleted_lines: from oslo_log import versionutils# The FederationDriverBase class is the set of driver methods from earlier # drivers that we still support, that have not been removed or modified. This # class is then used to created the augmented V8 and V9 version abstract driver # classes, without having to duplicate a lot of abstract method signatures. # If you remove a method from V9, then move the abstract methods from this Base # class to the V8 class. Do not modify any of the method signatures in the Base # class - changes should only be made in the V8 and subsequent classes. class FederationDriverV8(FederationDriverBase): """Removed or redefined methods from V8. Move the abstract methods of any methods removed or modified in later versions of the driver from FederationDriverBase to here. We maintain this so that legacy drivers, which will be a subclass of FederationDriverV8, can still reference them. """ @abc.abstractmethod def list_idps(self): """List all identity providers. :returns: list of idp refs :rtype: list of dicts :raises keystone.exception.IdentityProviderNotFound: If the IdP doesn't exist. """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover @abc.abstractmethod def list_sps(self): """List all service providers. :returns: List of service provider ref objects :rtype: list of dicts """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover class FederationDriverV9(FederationDriverBase): """New or redefined methods from V8. Add any new V9 abstract methods (or those with modified signatures) to this class. """ @abc.abstractmethod def list_idps(self, hints): """List all identity providers. :param hints: filter hints which the driver should implement if at all possible. :returns: list of idp refs :rtype: list of dicts :raises keystone.exception.IdentityProviderNotFound: If the IdP doesn't exist. """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover @abc.abstractmethod def list_sps(self, hints): """List all service providers. :param hints: filter hints which the driver should implement if at all possible. :returns: List of service provider ref objects :rtype: list of dicts :raises keystone.exception.ServiceProviderNotFound: If the SP doesn't exist. """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover class V9FederationWrapperForV8Driver(FederationDriverV9): """Wrapper class to supported a V8 legacy driver. In order to support legacy drivers without having to make the manager code driver-version aware, we wrap legacy drivers so that they look like the latest version. For the various changes made in a new driver, here are the actions needed in this wrapper: Method removed from new driver - remove the call-through method from this class, since the manager will no longer be calling it. Method signature (or meaning) changed - wrap the old method in a new signature here, and munge the input and output parameters accordingly. New method added to new driver - add a method to implement the new functionality here if possible. If that is not possible, then return NotImplemented, since we do not guarantee to support new functionality with legacy drivers. """ @versionutils.deprecated( as_of=versionutils.deprecated.MITAKA, what='keystone.federation.FederationDriverV8', in_favor_of='keystone.federation.FederationDriverV9', remove_in=+2) def __init__(self, wrapped_driver): self.driver = wrapped_driver def create_idp(self, idp_id, idp): return self.driver.create_idp(idp_id, idp) def delete_idp(self, idp_id): self.driver.delete_idp(idp_id) # NOTE(davechen): The hints is ignored here to support legacy drivers, # but the filters in hints will be remain unsatisfied and V3Controller # wrapper will apply these filters at the end. So that the result get # returned for list IdP will still be filtered with the legacy drivers. def list_idps(self, hints): return self.driver.list_idps() def get_idp(self, idp_id): return self.driver.get_idp(idp_id) def get_idp_from_remote_id(self, remote_id): return self.driver.get_idp_from_remote_id(remote_id) def update_idp(self, idp_id, idp): return self.driver.update_idp(idp_id, idp) def create_protocol(self, idp_id, protocol_id, protocol): return self.driver.create_protocol(idp_id, protocol_id, protocol) def update_protocol(self, idp_id, protocol_id, protocol): return self.driver.update_protocol(idp_id, protocol_id, protocol) def get_protocol(self, idp_id, protocol_id): return self.driver.get_protocol(idp_id, protocol_id) def list_protocols(self, idp_id): return self.driver.list_protocols(idp_id) def delete_protocol(self, idp_id, protocol_id): self.driver.delete_protocol(idp_id, protocol_id) def create_mapping(self, mapping_id, mapping): return self.driver.create_mapping(mapping_id, mapping) def delete_mapping(self, mapping_id): self.driver.delete_mapping(mapping_id) def update_mapping(self, mapping_id, mapping_ref): return self.driver.update_mapping(mapping_id, mapping_ref) def list_mappings(self): return self.driver.list_mappings() def get_mapping(self, mapping_id): return self.driver.get_mapping(mapping_id) def get_mapping_from_idp_and_protocol(self, idp_id, protocol_id): return self.driver.get_mapping_from_idp_and_protocol( idp_id, protocol_id) def create_sp(self, sp_id, sp): return self.driver.create_sp(sp_id, sp) def delete_sp(self, sp_id): self.driver.delete_sp(sp_id) # NOTE(davechen): The hints is ignored here to support legacy drivers, # but the filters in hints will be remain unsatisfied and V3Controller # wrapper will apply these filters at the end. So that the result get # returned for list SPs will still be filtered with the legacy drivers. def list_sps(self, hints): return self.driver.list_sps() def get_sp(self, sp_id): return self.driver.get_sp(sp_id) def update_sp(self, sp_id, sp): return self.driver.update_sp(sp_id, sp) def get_enabled_service_providers(self): return self.driver.get_enabled_service_providers()

commit_message:
Stop adding ServiceAvailable group option

Service available group already exists.Therefore we don't need to
register this group here again.

Change-Id: I9680abe0a177a80860ec6ba1dbacc04fac41758d
Closes-Bug: #1621036

commit_message:
Update RDO repo url for stable/newton

https://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos7-master will soon point to an
Ocata repository. For stable/newton, we can just switch the repo
URL to use centos7-newton, which is already available and has the
same contents.

Change-Id: Ia53f3b07f843986774b823c28aed6a0fe5908b10

commit_message:
Remove tempest.test usage from manila tests

Manila tempest tests should be independent from tempest code
as much as possible. The decorator test.attr is widely used in
all tests to set testcase attrs. This decorator doesn't
really do anyting else than calling testtools.testcase.attr.

Change-Id: If10beb9ae7562524f602a6fd7254aa95ef24d70e
Partially-Implements: bp tempest-no-deps

commit_message:
Volume detail support glance_metadata in CLI

Add supporting to allow list volumes
filtering by glance_metadata.

Cinder code has merged, support it in client.

Change-Id: Ifc2124b88c4199700d91a89c9fe68598630877db
Implements: blueprint support-volume-glance-metadata-query

commit_message:
Using assertIsNone() instead of assertIs(None, ..)

Following OpenStack Style Guidelines[1]:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#unit-tests-and-assertraises
[H203] Unit test assertions tend to give better messages for more
specific assertions. As a result, assertIsNone(...) is preferred
over assertEqual(None, ...) and assertIs(..,None).

Change-Id: I72327e4c740ef11ee9cba4cda9642e4a270d1b52

update test-requirements for new hacking

break. This change has merged in requirements repository and I'm
pushing this instead of waiting for the bot.
